newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia's Suharto urges non-oil exports boost.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia's Suharto urges non-oil exports boost.

text.p: Indonesia's President Suharto on Tuesday urged local businessmen to boost non-oil exports in a bid to trim a widening current account deficit.

"The challenges that we face include limited job opportunities, education and training and widening of the current account deficit," Suharto said in a speech while inaugurating an export products exhibition.
"In recent years we all have worked hard to increase non-oil exports....In the years to come, our task will be more difficult as the deficit is widening," Suharto said.
"I have said that the increase of non-oil exports must be a goal for the entire nation," Suharto said.
Industry and Trade Minister Tunky Ariwibowo, also speaking at the ceremony, said non-oil exports rose by 15.13 percent in 1995, compared with growth of 12.12 percent in 1994.

"The growth is below target. Imports of capital goods and consumption goods grew at 27.36 percent and 12.91 percent respectively in 1995. This caused a balance of payments deficit because total export values were lower than import values," Ariwibowo said.

"In the effort to increase exports to the government target of 19.2 percent growth a year, cooperation between government and private sectors is needed. The government will continue deregulation measures in all sectors, including cuts in levies," Ariwibowo said.
He said the government would also seek new markets for Indonesian goods.

Indonesia has estimated its current account deficit would widen to $8.7 billion in fiscal 1996/97 (April-March) or about four percent of gross domestic product (GDP), from $7.0 billion or about 3.2 percent of GDP in 1995/96.
